Award.AwardTitle: Testing the Effects of Real-time Scaffolding of Science Inquiry Driven by Automated Performance Assessment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project addresses how middle school students conduct scientific inquiry in complex domains. Expertise and methods from the learning sciences, science education, assessment, statistics, computer science, and educational data mining are combined in a program of work that: (1) uses knowledge engineering and data mining to develop methods for performance assessment of inquiry in earth and life sciences; (2) uses these performance algorithms to trigger a pedagogical agent that will provide individualized scaffolding to students in real time; and (3) studies the effects of that scaffolding. This project builds on an extensive body of prior research (including several NSF-supported projects) on STEM learning with simulations and assessments of STEM learning. The two main research questions seek to address the extent to which inquiry skills scaffolded by the pedagogical agent transfer across tasks within the same topic, and across topics within the same domain. Key activities to be conducted over the course of the three-year project include: (1) developing multiple types of scaffolds for the pedagogical agent; (2) pilot testing and analysis with students and teachers to drive iterative improvement; (3) developing (using knowledge engineered and data mined algorithms) and validating metrics to assess the inquiry skills of (a) hypothesis generation, (b) data collection, (c) data interpretation, and (d) warranting claims; (4) integrating assessment metrics with the pedagogical agent; and (5) data collection and analysis to address the research questions. Data collection will take place in five Massachusetts schools, comparing middle school students who do to those who do not receive inquiry scaffolding via the pedagogical agent (students randomly assigned to treatment conditions by topic). At the conclusion of the project, log data will be made freely available to scientific researchers for secondary research and teaching purposes via the Pittsburgh Science of Learning Center DataShop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 

This NSF REAL project resulted in the development and validation of science inquiry microworlds for middle school life and Earth science in the intelligent tutoring system, Inq-ITS. In addition, automated scoring and real-time, individualized scaffolding of students’ inquiry practice competencies within the Inq-ITS’ microworlds were implemented and validated. Studies conducted with middle school students showed the success of the system in terms of improved performance and transfer of inquiry practices as a result of scaffolding. Each of these valuable findings and contributions are outlined in more detail below.

 

In the initial phases of this project, several earth and life science microworlds were developed to support and assess students’ science inquiry competencies. Earth science microworld topics in Inq-ITS to date include: seasons, divergent boundaries, convergent boundaries, lunar phases, and eclipses. Life science microworld topics in Inq-ITS include: natural selection, diversity of traits, introduction to predation, advanced predation, animal cell (function and energy), plant cell (function and energy), and genetics. Automated scoring for life and Earth science microworlds was developed under the present project using knowledge engineering and educational data mining techniques. The scoring was used to capture students’ performance on inquiry practices including: asking questions/hypothesizing, planning and carrying out investigations/ collecting data, analyzing and interpreting data, and warranting claims. The automated scoring techniques were found to be extremely accurate when compared to human scoring of science inquiry practices (over 95% accuracy).

 

Real-time, individualized scaffolding was developed for all life and Earth science microworlds based on the automated scoring of inquiry practice. Scaffolds in Inq-ITS are delivered to students via the pedagogical agent, Rex. Scaffolds address students’ difficulties with particular components of inquiry practices at different levels of specificity (i.e. scaffolds range from orienting to procedural to conceptual to instrumental). These scaffolds were revised and formalized over the course of several iterations with teachers and students.

 

We have conducted multiple randomized-controlled studies over the course of the project in order to examine the extent to which inquiry skills scaffolded by the pedagogical agent transfer across tasks within the same topic, and across topics within the same domain. Within these studies, students were randomly assigned to treatment conditions (scaffolding or no scaffolding) by topic in order to compare the performance of students who students who do to those who do not receive inquiry scaffolding via the pedagogical agent. Results of the studies showed that students in both conditions (scaffolding and no scaffolding) improved their performance on inquiry practices with increasing use of Inq-ITS over time. Students who received scaffolding from the pedagogical agent Rex, however, improved at a greater rate. In addition, studies have shown that students’ inquiry practice performance transfers across microworld activities within the same topic and across topics within the same domain (i.e. Life or Earth Science).

 

Overall, this project provides a state-of-the-art, performance-based assessment to capture and support middle school students’ science inquiry competencies in the domains of Life and Earth science. These types of learning and assessment environments are critical in order to promote students’ future performance and interest in STEM.
